title: Question Tags

tasks.audioText: We are talking about the weather. It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
tasks.transcript: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?

options.text: The speaker confirms the weather is terrible.
The speaker expects agreement that the day is lovely.
The speaker asks what day of the week it is.
The speaker is unsure whether it is daytime or night.

tasks.explanation: A positive statement with a negative tag ('isn't it?') expects the listener to agree.

tasks.audioText: I'm checking our plans for Saturday. You don't work on weekends, do you?
tasks.transcript: You don't work on weekends, do you?

options.text: The speaker tells the listener to work on weekends.
The speaker confirms the listener works every weekend.
The speaker expects the listener is free on weekends and asks to confirm.
The speaker asks how many hours the listener works.

tasks.explanation: A negative statement with a positive tag ('do you?') seeks confirmation that the person doesn't work weekends.

tasks.audioText: The movie just finished. That was a great film, wasn't it?
tasks.transcript: That was a great film, wasn't it?

options.text: The speaker thinks the film was excellent and expects agreement.
The speaker did not enjoy the film at all.
The speaker is asking which film they watched.
The speaker wants to watch the film again tomorrow.

tasks.explanation: 'Was' is positive, so the tag is negative 'wasn't it?' — the speaker seeks agreement that the film was great.

tasks.audioText: I noticed Emma at the café this morning. She hasn't left the country yet, has she?
tasks.transcript: She hasn't left the country yet, has she?

options.text: The speaker confirms Emma already left the country.
The speaker believes Emma is still here and asks for confirmation.
The speaker wants Emma to leave the country.
The speaker is asking which country Emma is from.

tasks.explanation: Negative statement ('hasn't left') with positive tag ('has she?') — the speaker expects Emma is still in the country.

tasks.audioText: Let me remind you about the meeting. You will be there at three o'clock, won't you?
tasks.transcript: You will be there at three o'clock, won't you?

options.text: The speaker asks the listener to confirm attendance at three.
The speaker cancels the three o'clock meeting.
The speaker asks what time the meeting starts.
The speaker says the meeting was yesterday at three.

tasks.explanation: 'Will' is positive, tag is 'won't you?' — the speaker expects confirmation of attendance.

tasks.audioText: We are discussing our neighbours. They have moved to a new house, haven't they?
tasks.transcript: They have moved to a new house, haven't they?

options.text: The speaker asks if the neighbours are planning to move.
The speaker says the neighbours have not moved.
The speaker believes the neighbours moved and seeks confirmation.
The speaker is inviting the neighbours to a new house.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'have moved' with negative tag 'haven't they?' — the speaker is fairly sure they moved and wants confirmation.

tasks.audioText: I can hear music from the living room. The children can play the piano, can't they?
tasks.transcript: The children can play the piano, can't they?

options.text: The speaker asks if the children are allowed to buy a piano.
The speaker believes the children have the ability to play piano and asks to confirm.
The speaker says the children cannot play any instrument.
The speaker wants the children to stop playing music.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'can play' with negative 'can't they?' — the speaker expects confirmation of the children's ability.

tasks.audioText: I saw your test results on the table. You passed the exam, didn't you?
tasks.transcript: You passed the exam, didn't you?

options.text: The speaker asks when the exam will take place.
The speaker says the listener failed the exam.
The speaker believes the listener passed and wants confirmation.
The speaker is offering to help study for the exam.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'passed' with negative 'didn't you?' — the speaker is fairly confident and seeks agreement.

tasks.audioText: We are looking at the restaurant bill. The food wasn't very expensive, was it?
tasks.transcript: The food wasn't very expensive, was it?

options.text: The speaker thinks the food was cheap and expects agreement.
The speaker is complaining that the food was too expensive.
The speaker is asking what they ordered.
The speaker says the food was the most expensive ever.

tasks.explanation: Negative 'wasn't expensive' with positive tag 'was it?' — the speaker believes the price was reasonable.

tasks.audioText: I see you have a new phone. You bought it online, didn't you?
tasks.transcript: You bought it online, didn't you?

options.text: The speaker is sure the phone was bought in a physical store.
The speaker asks how much the phone costs.
The speaker thinks it was an online purchase and seeks confirmation.
The speaker wants to sell a phone online.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'bought it online' with negative 'didn't you?' — the speaker believes it was online and checks.

tasks.audioText: I remember the conversation yesterday. He should apologise to her, shouldn't he?
tasks.transcript: He should apologise to her, shouldn't he?

options.text: The speaker says he already apologised.
The speaker believes an apology is needed and expects agreement.
The speaker thinks she should apologise, not he.
The speaker asks who started the argument.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'should apologise' with negative 'shouldn't he?' — the speaker expects the listener to agree.

tasks.audioText: We are talking about our colleague. She doesn't speak French, does she?
tasks.transcript: She doesn't speak French, does she?

options.text: The speaker is confident that she speaks French fluently.
The speaker believes she does not speak French and wants to verify.
The speaker is asking her to translate something into French.
The speaker says she is learning French now.

tasks.explanation: Negative 'doesn't speak' with positive 'does she?' — the speaker expects the answer is no.

tasks.audioText: I'm checking the schedule with my friend. We are meeting at six, aren't we?
tasks.transcript: We are meeting at six, aren't we?

options.text: The speaker confirms a meeting time of six and asks for agreement.
The speaker cancels the meeting completely.
The speaker proposes meeting at seven instead.
The speaker says they already met at six yesterday.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'are meeting' with negative 'aren't we?' — the speaker double-checks the agreed time.

tasks.audioText: I noticed you look well. You've been exercising regularly, haven't you?
tasks.transcript: You've been exercising regularly, haven't you?

options.text: The speaker thinks the listener stopped exercising recently.
The speaker believes the listener has been working out and wants confirmation.
The speaker suggests starting a new exercise program.
The speaker says the listener looks unwell.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'have been exercising' with negative 'haven't you?' — the speaker notices the result and expects a yes.

tasks.audioText: The streets are wet this morning. It rained last night, didn't it?
tasks.transcript: It rained last night, didn't it?

options.text: The speaker is sure it did not rain last night.
The speaker asks if it will rain tonight.
The speaker believes it rained and asks for confirmation based on evidence.
The speaker says the streets are completely dry.

tasks.explanation: Positive 'rained' with negative 'didn't it?' — the wet streets are evidence, and the speaker expects agreement.

short_description: Разделительные вопросы: ..., isn't it? / ..., don't you?
